questions.text: A 3-month-old girl baby is brought to the OPD by her mother with complaints of a clicking sound originating from the hip region of the baby. On examination, it was found that Ortolani’s test was positive and the x-ray showed developmental dysplasia of the hip. What is the next line of management?

options.label: D
options.text: Closed reduction and Pavlik harness application

questions.correct_answer: D. Closed reduction and Pavlik harness application
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Closed reduction and Pavlik harness application In newborn babies and infants up-to 6 months of age closed reduction and Pavlik harness application is the treatment of choice In newborn babies and infants up-to 6 months of age closed reduction and Pavlik harness application is the treatment of choice. X-ray or ultrasound should be done to confirm the reduction of the hip joint. The stability of the reduction should also be assessed 2-4 weeks afterwards by getting an x-ray done.

Highyeild:

DDH ● CDH - Congenital dislocation of hip DDH - Developmental dysplasia of hip ● Etiology - proposed factors: - Ligamentous laxity of hip capsule (F>M) - Prenatal positioning - breech - Postnatal posturing - Primary acetabular dysplasia - More in western countries > Asian - Treatment AGE TT 1-6 Months 6-18 Months 8-24 months 24 months Pavlik harness Traction with CR (+)→ Cast x 3 months ↓ (-) Open Reduction Attempt for CR/OR→ Osteotomy, usually not Needed Osteotomy or OR + Femoral shortening

In newborn babies and infants up to 6 months of age closed reduction and Pavlik harness application is the treatment of choice, not hip spica. Option C. Open reduction is only done when closed reduction fails

questions.text: Which is the most important risk of reduction in developmental dysplasia of the hip?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Avascular necrosis The risk of avascular necrosis can be seen in all forms of treatment in DDH either surgical or conservative. Causes include extrinsic compression of vasculature supplying the femoral capital epiphysis , excessive direct pressure on the cartilaginous femoral head The risk of avascular necrosis can be seen in all forms of treatment in DDH either surgical or conservative.Excessive forceful abduction is also a risk factor for AVN and should be avoided.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. The most important risk of reduction in developmental dysplasia of thehip is avascular necrosis, not failure to achieve the reduction Option: B. - The most important risk of reduction in developmental dysplasia of hip is avascular necrosis, not the recurrence of dislocation Option: C. - The most important risk of reduction in developmental dysplasia of the hip is avascular necrosis, not femoral fracture

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the orthopedic OPD with complaints of limping for the past two days and is now unable to bear weight. He complains of pain in the right hip and knee. There is a restriction of movement of the right hip joint. He has been having a running fever for the past week. Blood investigations revealed a WBC count of 14*10(9) and ESR was 79 mm/hr. what is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. Septic arthritis of the hip
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Septic arthritis of the hip Four important parameters have been identified to diagnose septic arthritis of hip - inability to bear weight history of fever wbc count of > 12*10(9) 4. esr > 40 mm/hr. If all four parameters are positive, the predicted probability of septic arthritis is 99.6%.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. No clinical features of transient synovitis of the hip- Transient synovitis is an inflammation in the hip joint that causes pain, limp, and sometimes refusal to bear weight. Option: C. No clinical features of Perthes disease- Stiffness and reduced range of movement in the hip joint. Pain in the knee, thigh, or groin when putting weight on the affected leg or moving the hip joint. thinner thigh muscles on the affected leg. shortening of the affected leg, leading to uneven leg length. Option: D. No clinical features of Slipped upper femoral epiphysis pain in their groin , hip, thigh, and/or knee – some children only have knee pain, even though the condition affects the hip. A limp, or holding their leg in an unusual resting position . Reduced movement of their hip joint . A slight shortening of the affected leg.

6 months to 6 years: Up to 2 years : Reduce the head into the acetabulum by closed methods. After 2 years: It is difficult to attempt closed reduction. Because of the risk of avascular necrosis of the femoral head. questions.text: All the following are useful in the diagnosis of congenital dislocation of the hip except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gaenslen test Gaenslen test is used to test pathology in the sacroiliac joint Gaenslen's test, also known as Gaenslen's maneuver, is used to detect musculoskeletal abnormalities and primary-chronic inflammation of the lumbar vertebrae and sacroiliac joint.

Highyeild:

Neonate → Barlow Test (Most Provocative test): Adduct hips and give a gentle push → it will dislocate hip Ortolani: Abduct + pull Alli's test/Galeazzi sign: Compare the positions of knees Infant: If the hip is not reducible → limited abduction - Most reliable sign of dislocated hip. Shortening (Galeazzi sign) Asymmetry of thigh folds

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Ortolani's test is a test for DDH, the hips, and knees are held in a flexed position and gradually abducted. A 'click of entrance' will be felt as the femoral head slips into the acetabulum from the position of dislocation. Option B. - Barlow's test is a test for DDH Barlow’s sign -Attempts to subluxate or dislocate the femoral head from within the acetabulum. The child is made to lie supine on an examination table. The examiner holds the thigh with the thumb on the anterior side of the thigh and fingers on the posterior aspect. The hips are adducted, and a gentle push is applied to slide the hips posteriorly. This will dislocate the head of the femur from the acetabulum. This is the most provocative test for DDH. Option D - Vascular sign of Narath is a test for DDH In posterior dislocation of the hip, the joint fall on the femoral artery and causes a feeble or absent femoral pulse. Known as the vascular sign of Narath.

questions.text: Which of the following regarding congenital dislocation of the Hip is false?

options.label: A
options.text: The femoral head and acetabulum are normal

options.label: B
options.text: This disorder is more common in females than in males

options.label: C
options.text: Family history of congenital dysplasia of the hip increases the likelihood of this condition to approx. 10 percent

options.label: D
options.text: CDH incidence is very high in breech deliveries

questions.correct_answer: A. The femoral head and acetabulum are normal
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The femoral head and acetabulum are normal Femoral neck is excessively anteverted and Acetabulum is shallow , with a steeply sloping roof in CDH

Highyeild:

● Congenital dislocation of the Hip This is a spontaneous dislocation of the hip occurring before, during, or shortly after birth. CDH is more common in ● First-born babies, ● More on the left, ● More common in females (M: F=1:5), ● Bilateral in 20 percent of cases AETIOLOGY ● Hereditary predisposition to joint laxity ● Hormone-induced joint laxity: ● Breech malposition: PATHOLOGY ● The femoral head is dislocated upwards and laterally; ● Its epiphysis is small and ossifies late. ● The femoral neck is excessively anteverted. ● Acetabulum is shallow, with a steeply sloping roof.

questions.text: The most provocative test for CDH is which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Barlow test The Barlow maneuver is a provocation test conducted by adducting the ﬂexed hip and applying gentle anterior- to-posterior pressure in order to push the femoral head superior and posterior over the edge of a shallow acetabulum.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. The Barlow and Ortolani tests are the mainstays in the examination of the newborn But the Barlow maneuver is a provocation test It is the reverse of the B arlow test: The examiner grasps the child’s thigh between the thumb and the index finger and, with the fourth and fifth fingers, lifts the greater trochanter while simultaneously abducting the hip. When the test result is positive, the femoral head will slip into the socket with a delicate “clunk” that is palpable but not audible. Option:B. Galeazzi's test is used to look for limb length discrepancy Galeazzi sign/Alli’s test : The child is supine on the bed and placing both hips in 90 degrees of flexion and comparing the height of the knees . The affected side is at a lower level. As the thigh is foreshortened, there will be more thigh folds on the affected side than on the normal side. Option:D. Telescoping is another test done in DDH The telescoping test is used to check for hip dislocations . To perform the test the patient lies down flat on their back. The physical therapist then raises one of the patient's legs up so that the knee is bent at a 90-degree angle
